Justification: SaaS company needs formal IS security policies covering cloud, data, and users.
Related Risks: R-01: Weak security governance
Evidence / Implementation: Information Security Policy, Acceptable Use Policy, policy approvals.

Justification: Roles for security, DevOps, product, and compliance must be defined.
Related Risks: R-02: Unclear responsibility for security tasks
Evidence / Implementation: Org chart, job descriptions, RACI matrix.

Justification: Prevent one person from controlling code, infra and approvals in AWS/CI-CD.
Related Risks: R-03: Unauthorized or unreviewed production changes
Evidence / Implementation: SoD matrix, IAM role separation, approval workflows in CI-CD.

Justification: Management must support ISMS and enforce controls for ISO 27001.
Related Risks: R-04: Lack of management support
Evidence / Implementation: ISMS charter, management commitment statement, meeting minutes.

Justification: SaaS in Qatar must contact regulators/authorities in case of incidents.
Related Risks: R-05: Delayed or incorrect regulatory notifications
Evidence / Implementation: Authority contact list, IR plan with escalation steps.

Justification: Membership in security/cloud groups helps receive threat and best-practice info.
Related Risks: R-06: Missing latest security/cloud guidance
Evidence / Implementation: Memberships, mailing lists, event records.

Justification: SaaS on AWS must collect and use threat intel (cloud, web app, regional).
Related Risks: R-07: Undetected emerging threats
Evidence / Implementation: TI feeds, vendor reports, internal procedures for using TI.

Justification: Security must be built into product and feature projects from the start.
Related Risks: R-08: Projects go live without security review
Evidence / Implementation: Project templates including security tasks, security review checkpoints.

Control Name: Inventory of information and other associated assets
Justification: Need inventory of data, systems, AWS resources, laptops, etc.
Related Risks: R-09: Unmanaged or unknown assets
Evidence / Implementation: Asset register, CMDB, AWS resource inventory.

Control Name: Acceptable use of information and other associated assets
Justification: Define how staff may use laptops, SaaS tools, cloud access.
Related Risks: R-10: Misuse of company assets
Evidence / Implementation: Acceptable Use Policy, HR acknowledgement records.

Justification: Ensure assets (laptops, tokens, accounts) are returned/removed on exit.
Related Risks: R-11: Ex-employees retain access or data
Evidence / Implementation: Offboarding checklist, asset return forms, account de-provisioning logs.

Justification: SaaS must classify customer data, internal docs, logs, etc.
Related Risks: R-12: Inconsistent protection of sensitive data
Evidence / Implementation: Data classification policy, data handling guidelines.

Justification: Classified information should be labelled in tools and documents.
Related Risks: R-13: Staff cannot see data sensitivity
Evidence / Implementation: Labelling rules, examples in tools (DLP labels, doc templates).

Justification: Secure transfer of data between customers, third-parties and AWS.
Related Risks: R-14: Data interception or leakage in transit
Evidence / Implementation: Encryption in transit, secure file transfer procedures.

Justification: Overall access control principles for SaaS systems and AWS.
Related Risks: R-15: Excessive or unmanaged access
Evidence / Implementation: Access Control Policy, role-based access model.

Justification: Central identity for employees and admins (IdP, SSO).
Related Risks: R-16: Orphaned or duplicate identities
Evidence / Implementation: IdP configuration, joiner/mover/leaver process.

Justification: Rules for passwords, MFA, API keys, secret storage.
Related Risks: R-17: Compromise of weak or shared credentials
Evidence / Implementation: Password policy, MFA enforcement, secret vault usage.

Justification: Provisioning, review, and removal of access rights.
Related Risks: R-18: Users keep unnecessary access
Evidence / Implementation: Access request workflow, periodic access reviews.

Justification: SaaS relies on AWS and other vendors; security must be managed.
Related Risks: R-19: Vendor-related data breach
Evidence / Implementation: Vendor security requirements, due-diligence checklist.

Control Name: Addressing information security within supplier agreements
Justification: Contracts must include security, data protection, and SLA clauses.
Related Risks: R-20: Contracts missing security terms
Evidence / Implementation: Standard contractual clauses, DPAs, SLAs.

Control Name: Managing information security in the ICT supply chain
Justification: Need oversight of all ICT providers (cloud, payment, monitoring).
Related Risks: R-21: Supply-chain attack or outage
Evidence / Implementation: Supplier inventory, risk assessments, monitoring of critical suppliers.

Control Name: Monitoring, review and change management of supplier services
Justification: Regularly review supplier performance and changes.
Related Risks: R-22: Unnoticed changes increasing risk
Evidence / Implementation: Vendor review meetings, performance reports, change notices.

Control Name: Information security for use of cloud services
Justification: Core for AWS-based SaaS; must govern secure selection and use of cloud.
Related Risks: R-23: Misconfigured or insecure cloud services
Evidence / Implementation: Cloud security policy, CSPM reports, AWS best-practice baselines.

Control Name: Information security incident management planning and preparation
Justification: Need defined plan, roles, and tools for incidents.
Related Risks: R-24: Poor response to incidents
Evidence / Implementation: Incident Response Plan, playbooks, on-call rota.

Control Name: Assessment and decision on information security events
Justification: Process to triage events and decide if they are incidents.
Related Risks: R-25: Important events ignored
Evidence / Implementation: Event classification criteria, triage procedures.

Justification: Actions to contain, eradicate, and recover from incidents.
Related Risks: R-26: Extended impact of incidents
Evidence / Implementation: IR procedures, tickets, post-incident reports.

Justification: Capture lessons learned and improve controls.
Related Risks: R-27: Repeated similar incidents
Evidence / Implementation: Lessons-learned reports, corrective action logs.

Justification: Proper evidence handling for investigations and legal needs.
Related Risks: R-28: Evidence not admissible or complete
Evidence / Implementation: Chain-of-custody procedure, evidence storage rules.

Justification: Ensure security is maintained during outages or crises.
Related Risks: R-29: Security bypassed during disruptions
Evidence / Implementation: BCP procedures including security steps.

Justification: IT and cloud must support recovery objectives.
Related Risks: R-30: Prolonged downtime of SaaS platform
Evidence / Implementation: DR plans, RTO/RPO definitions, AWS multi-AZ setup.

Control Name: Identification of legal, statutory, regulatory and contractual requirements
Justification: SaaS in Qatar must track legal and contractual security requirements.
Related Risks: R-31: Non-compliance with laws or contracts
Evidence / Implementation: Compliance register, legal requirement inventory.

Justification: Need to protect software IP, licenses, and third-party IP.
Related Risks: R-32: IP infringement or loss
Evidence / Implementation: IP policy, license records, NDA templates.

Justification: Business and security records must be retained and protected.
Related Risks: R-33: Loss or tampering of important records
Evidence / Implementation: Record retention policy, backups, access controls.

Justification: SaaS processes customer PII and must protect it under applicable laws.
Related Risks: R-34: Personal data breach
Evidence / Implementation: Privacy policy, DPIAs, data subject procedures.

Justification: Periodic independent review of ISMS is required.
Related Risks: R-35: Undetected weaknesses in ISMS
Evidence / Implementation: Audit reports, management review outputs.

Control Name: Compliance with policies and standards for information security
Justification: Need to monitor adherence to policies and standards.
Related Risks: R-36: Policy violations going unnoticed
Evidence / Implementation: Compliance checks, internal audits, KPI reports.

Justification: Standard procedures for key operational and security tasks.
Related Risks: R-37: Inconsistent or insecure operations
Evidence / Implementation: SOPs, runbooks, change guides.

Justification: Background checks for staff accessing sensitive SaaS data and AWS infrastructure.
Related Risks: R-38: Hiring untrustworthy personnel
Evidence / Implementation: Background check policy, vendor screening reports.

Justification: Employment contracts must include security and confidentiality obligations.
Related Risks: R-39: Staff unclear on security duties
Evidence / Implementation: Employment contracts, NDA clauses, signed acknowledgements.

Control Name: Information security awareness, education and training
Justification: All staff must receive security awareness training relevant to SaaS and cloud.
Related Risks: R-40: Staff make security mistakes
Evidence / Implementation: Training records, e-learning platform, phishing simulation results.

Justification: Formal process for handling security policy violations.
Related Risks: R-41: No deterrent for policy violations
Evidence / Implementation: Disciplinary policy, incident records, HR procedures.

Control Name: Responsibilities after termination or change of employment
Justification: Security responsibilities continue during notice period and post-exit.
Related Risks: R-42: Data theft or sabotage by departing staff
Evidence / Implementation: Exit interview checklist, post-termination obligations in contract.

Justification: NDAs for employees, contractors, and third-parties accessing confidential data.
Related Risks: R-43: Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information
Evidence / Implementation: NDA templates, signed NDA register.

Justification: Security controls for remote staff accessing SaaS platform and AWS.
Related Risks: R-44: Insecure remote access or endpoints
Evidence / Implementation: Remote work policy, VPN/MFA requirements, endpoint security.

Justification: Staff must know how and when to report security events and incidents.
Related Risks: R-45: Unreported security events
Evidence / Implementation: Reporting procedure, incident reporting channel, training materials.

Justification: Office and data center perimeter security (if applicable).
Related Risks: R-46: Unauthorized physical access
Evidence / Implementation: Perimeter fencing, access gates, CCTV.

Justification: Controlled entry to offices and server rooms (if on-premise exists).
Related Risks: R-47: Tailgating or unauthorized entry
Evidence / Implementation: Access cards, visitor logs, reception.

Justification: Physical security for office spaces and meeting rooms with sensitive discussions.
Related Risks: R-48: Eavesdropping or theft in offices
Evidence / Implementation: Locked doors, visitor escort policy.

Justification: CCTV and monitoring of physical premises.
Related Risks: R-49: Physical intrusion undetected
Evidence / Implementation: CCTV system, monitoring logs, security guard patrols.

Control Name: Protecting against physical and environmental threats
Justification: Protection from fire, flood, power loss in office/server room.
Related Risks: R-50: Physical damage to infrastructure
Evidence / Implementation: Fire suppression, UPS, environmental monitoring.

Justification: Special areas with additional controls for sensitive work.
Related Risks: R-51: Sensitive operations compromised
Evidence / Implementation: Secure room designation, access logs.

Justification: Policy requiring staff to clear desks and lock screens when away.
Related Risks: R-52: Information exposure via unattended workstations
Evidence / Implementation: Clear desk policy, screen lock enforcement, awareness training.

Justification: Physical protection of equipment (servers, networking, staff devices).
Related Risks: R-53: Damage or theft of equipment
Evidence / Implementation: Equipment placement guidelines, physical locks.

Justification: Controls for laptops and devices taken offsite by remote workers.
Related Risks: R-54: Loss or theft of mobile devices
Evidence / Implementation: Device encryption, remote wipe, tracking policy.

Justification: Secure handling of USB drives, backups, portable storage.
Related Risks: R-55: Data leakage via removable media
Evidence / Implementation: Media handling policy, encryption of removable media.

Justification: Power, cooling, and network utilities for infrastructure.
Related Risks: R-56: Service disruption due to utility failure
Evidence / Implementation: UPS systems, backup generators, redundant ISP.

Justification: Protection of network and power cabling from damage or interception.
Related Risks: R-57: Cable damage or tapping
Evidence / Implementation: Cable conduits, restricted access to wiring closets.

Justification: Regular maintenance of physical IT equipment and facilities.
Related Risks: R-58: Equipment failure from poor maintenance
Evidence / Implementation: Maintenance schedules, vendor contracts, logs.

Control Name: Secure disposal or re-use of equipment
Justification: Sanitize storage devices before disposal or reuse.
Related Risks: R-59: Data recovery from discarded equipment
Evidence / Implementation: Data wiping procedures, certificate of destruction.

Justification: Security of laptops, desktops, mobile devices accessing SaaS and AWS.
Related Risks: R-60: Compromised endpoint devices
Evidence / Implementation: EDR/antivirus, device hardening, patch management.

Justification: Control and monitor privileged access to AWS and SaaS admin consoles.
Related Risks: R-61: Abuse of privileged access
Evidence / Implementation: Privileged access management (PAM), MFA for admins, audit logs.

Justification: Restrict access to data and systems based on need-to-know and roles.
Related Risks: R-62: Unauthorized data access
Evidence / Implementation: RBAC policies, least privilege enforcement.

Justification: Control access to source code repositories (GitHub, GitLab, etc.).
Related Risks: R-63: Source code theft or tampering
Evidence / Implementation: Repository access controls, MFA, audit logs.

Justification: Strong authentication mechanisms (MFA, SSO) for all systems.
Related Risks: R-64: Weak authentication leading to compromise
Evidence / Implementation: MFA enforcement, SSO configuration, password policies.

Justification: Monitor and manage capacity of AWS resources and SaaS platform.
Related Risks: R-65: Performance degradation or outages
Evidence / Implementation: CloudWatch monitoring, auto-scaling, capacity planning.

Justification: Antivirus, anti-malware on endpoints and scanning of file uploads.
Related Risks: R-66: Malware infection
Evidence / Implementation: EDR/antivirus, file scanning in uploads, patch management.

Justification: Regular vulnerability scanning and patching of systems and applications.
Related Risks: R-67: Exploitation of unpatched vulnerabilities
Evidence / Implementation: Vulnerability scanner, patch management process, remediation tracking.

Justification: Secure baseline configurations for AWS services and application components.
Related Risks: R-68: Misconfigured systems leading to breaches
Evidence / Implementation: Configuration baselines, AWS Config, infrastructure as code.

Justification: Secure deletion of customer data and sensitive information when no longer needed.
Related Risks: R-69: Retention of unnecessary sensitive data
Evidence / Implementation: Data retention policy, automated deletion procedures.

Justification: Mask or anonymize sensitive data in non-production environments.
Related Risks: R-70: Exposure of real data in test/dev
Evidence / Implementation: Data masking tools, test data generation procedures.

Justification: DLP controls to prevent unauthorized data exfiltration.
Related Risks: R-71: Data leakage via email or web
Evidence / Implementation: DLP solution, monitoring rules, alerts.

Justification: Regular backups of SaaS platform data and AWS configurations.
Related Risks: R-72: Data loss from system failure
Evidence / Implementation: Automated backup schedules, backup testing, off-site storage.

Justification: High availability and redundancy for critical SaaS components in AWS.
Related Risks: R-73: Single point of failure
Evidence / Implementation: Multi-AZ deployment, load balancers, failover mechanisms.

Justification: Comprehensive logging of security events, access, and system activities.
Related Risks: R-74: Inability to detect or investigate incidents
Evidence / Implementation: Centralized logging (CloudWatch, SIEM), log retention policy.

Justification: Continuous monitoring of logs, security events, and system health.
Related Risks: R-75: Delayed detection of security incidents
Evidence / Implementation: SIEM, security monitoring dashboards, alerting rules.

Justification: Synchronized time across all systems for accurate logging and correlation.
Related Risks: R-76: Inaccurate timestamps in logs
Evidence / Implementation: NTP configuration, time sync monitoring.

Justification: Control use of system utilities that can bypass security controls.
Related Risks: R-77: Misuse of privileged utilities
Evidence / Implementation: Restricted access, logging of utility usage.

Control Name: Installation of software on operational systems
Justification: Controlled process for installing software on production systems.
Related Risks: R-78: Unauthorized or vulnerable software installed
Evidence / Implementation: Change management, software approval process, whitelist.

Justification: Segmentation, firewalls, security groups in AWS VPC.
Related Risks: R-79: Lateral movement in network
Evidence / Implementation: Network segmentation, security groups, NACLs, firewall rules.

Justification: Secure configuration and monitoring of network services.
Related Risks: R-80: Vulnerable network services exploited
Evidence / Implementation: Service hardening, regular reviews, vulnerability scanning.

Justification: Separate production, development, and management networks.
Related Risks: R-81: Cross-contamination between environments
Evidence / Implementation: VPC separation, subnet isolation, network policies.

Justification: Web filtering to block malicious sites and inappropriate content.
Related Risks: R-82: Malware download or phishing via web
Evidence / Implementation: Web proxy/filtering solution, URL blacklists.

Justification: Encryption of data at rest and in transit (TLS, KMS, EBS encryption).
Related Risks: R-83: Data exposure due to lack of encryption
Evidence / Implementation: Encryption policies, AWS KMS, TLS enforcement.

Justification: Security integrated into SDLC from requirements to deployment.
Related Risks: R-84: Insecure code deployed to production
Evidence / Implementation: SDLC procedures, security gates, DevSecOps practices.

Justification: Define security requirements for new features and applications.
Related Risks: R-85: Applications missing critical security controls
Evidence / Implementation: Security requirements templates, threat modeling.

Control Name: Secure system architecture and engineering principles
Justification: Apply security principles (defense in depth, least privilege) in design.
Related Risks: R-86: Architecturally weak systems
Evidence / Implementation: Architecture review process, security design patterns.

Justification: Developers follow secure coding standards (OWASP, CWE).
Related Risks: R-87: Common coding vulnerabilities
Evidence / Implementation: Secure coding guidelines, code review checklists, training.

Control Name: Security testing in development and acceptance
Justification: SAST, DAST, penetration testing before production release.
Related Risks: R-88: Vulnerabilities not detected before release
Evidence / Implementation: Security testing tools (SAST/DAST), penetration test reports.

Justification: Security requirements for third-party developers and contractors.
Related Risks: R-89: Insecure code from outsourced teams
Evidence / Implementation: Contractor security clauses, code review, access controls.

Control Name: Separation of development, test and production environments
Justification: Strict separation of dev, test, staging, and production in AWS.
Related Risks: R-90: Production data compromised via dev/test
Evidence / Implementation: Separate AWS accounts/VPCs, access controls, data masking.

Justification: Formal change management process for all production changes.
Related Risks: R-91: Unauthorized or failed changes cause outages
Evidence / Implementation: Change approval workflow, change logs, rollback procedures.

Justification: Use of sanitized or synthetic data for testing, not production data.
Related Risks: R-92: Real customer data exposed in test environments
Evidence / Implementation: Test data policy, data masking/anonymization.

Control Name: Protection of information systems during audit and testing
Justification: Ensure audits and security tests do not disrupt production systems.
Related Risks: R-93: Audit/test activities cause service disruption
Evidence / Implementation: Audit coordination procedures, read-only access for auditors, test schedules.
